questions.question: A taxpayer is starting a business and wants to avoid double taxation while having limited liability. Which entity type accomplishes both goals?

options.B: S corporation

questions.explanation: S corporations provide limited liability (corporate form) while avoiding double taxation through pass-through treatment. C corps have double taxation; partnerships and sole proprietorships don't provide full liability protection.
questions.tip: S corp = limited liability + pass-through taxation. Best of both worlds for many.

questions.question: Under check-the-box regulations, what is the default federal tax classification for a domestic LLC with two members?

options.B: S corporation

questions.explanation: A domestic LLC with two or more members defaults to partnership taxation under check-the-box rules. Single-member LLCs default to disregarded entity status. Either can elect corporate treatment.
questions.tip: LLC defaults: Single member = disregarded; Multi-member = partnership. Can elect corp.

questions.question: An owner materially participates in their business and wants to minimize self-employment tax. Which entity type provides the best opportunity?

options.B: LLC taxed as sole proprietorship
options.D: All entities have the same SE tax

questions.explanation: S corporation distributions to shareholders are not subject to self-employment tax. Only reasonable wages are subject to payroll taxes. LLCs taxed as partnerships or sole proprietorships subject all SE income to SE tax.
questions.tip: S corp SE tax savings: Only wages subject to payroll tax, not distributions.

questions.question: The Section 199A qualified business income deduction is available to owners of which entity types?

options.B: Pass-through entities only (S corps, partnerships, sole proprietorships)

questions.explanation: Section 199A provides up to a 20% deduction on qualified business income from pass-through entities (S corps, partnerships, LLCs, sole proprietorships). C corporation income is not eligible.
questions.tip: Section 199A = pass-through entities only. C corp income doesn't qualify.

questions.question: For purposes of Section 267 (related party rules), what ownership percentage creates a relationship between an individual and a corporation?

options.B: More than 25%

questions.explanation: Under Section 267, an individual and corporation are related parties if the individual owns (directly or constructively) more than 50% in value of the corporation's stock. Different thresholds apply to other relationship types.
questions.tip: Section 267: Individual-corporation relationship requires >50% ownership.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder wants to deduct a loss. Which limitation applies first?

options.B: At-risk limitation

questions.explanation: S corp loss limitations apply in order: (1) stock and debt basis, (2) at-risk, (3) passive activity, (4) excess business loss (Section 461(l)). Losses must clear each hurdle to be deductible.
questions.tip: S corp loss order: Basis → At-risk → Passive → Excess business loss.

questions.question: Two C corporations are a brother-sister controlled group if five or fewer individuals own more than 50% of each corporation (considering identical ownership). What additional test must be met?

options.B: More than 80% identical ownership
options.C: More than 80% total ownership by same individuals
options.D: Same individuals must be officers of both corporations

questions.explanation: Brother-sister controlled groups require: (1) five or fewer persons own more than 50% of each corporation (identical ownership), AND (2) the same persons own more than 80% of each corporation (total combined ownership test).
questions.tip: Brother-sister: >50% identical + >80% combined ownership by same 5 or fewer persons.

questions.question: A taxpayer owns qualified small business stock (QSBS) for more than 5 years. Under Section 1202, what percentage of gain may be excluded?
questions.explanation: QSBS exclusion depends on acquisition date: 50% for stock acquired before Feb 2009, 75% for Feb 2009-Sept 2010, and 100% for stock acquired after Sept 27, 2010. The 5-year holding period must be met.
questions.tip: QSBS exclusion: 100% for post-Sept 2010 acquisitions. Earlier dates have lower exclusions.

questions.question: A taxpayer owns two companies that transact with each other. What standard must intercompany transactions meet to avoid IRS adjustment?

options.B: Arm's length standard

questions.explanation: Related party transactions must reflect arm's length pricing—what unrelated parties would charge in comparable circumstances. The IRS can reallocate income under Section 482 if prices don't meet this standard.
questions.tip: Related party pricing = arm's length. IRS Section 482 authority to reallocate income.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder-employee receives only distributions (no salary). What is the tax risk?

options.A: No risk—distributions are never subject to payroll tax
options.B: IRS may recharacterize distributions as wages subject to payroll taxes

questions.explanation: Shareholder-employees must receive reasonable compensation for services. The IRS may recharacterize distributions as wages, subjecting them to employment taxes plus penalties and interest. Taking only distributions is a common audit target.
questions.tip: S corp reasonable compensation required. IRS targets all-distribution arrangements.

questions.question: A C corporation converts to S corporation status. Which built-in gains concern arises?

options.B: Built-in gains recognized within 5 years are subject to corporate-level tax
options.C: Gains are never taxable after conversion
options.D: Only real estate gains are taxable

questions.explanation: The built-in gains tax (Section 1374) imposes corporate-level tax on built-in gains recognized within 5 years of C-to-S conversion (reduced from 10 years). This prevents avoiding C corp tax by converting before selling appreciated assets.
questions.tip: BIG tax: 5-year recognition period for built-in gains on C-to-S conversion.

questions.question: A business owner separates real estate into a holding company that leases to the operating company. What is a primary benefit of this structure?

options.B: Protects real estate from operating company liabilities
options.C: Converts ordinary income to capital gains
options.D: Avoids self-employment tax on all income

questions.explanation: Separating real estate into a holding company provides asset protection. If the operating company faces liabilities or bankruptcy, the real estate is held separately and protected from creditors of the operating business.
questions.tip: Holding company structure: Asset protection is primary benefit. Tax planning is secondary.

questions.question: A taxpayer owns three separate businesses. For Section 199A purposes, when can these be aggregated?

options.A: Always—all businesses owned by same person aggregate
options.B: When they share centralized business elements and have 50%+ common ownership
options.C: Only if all are in the same industry

questions.explanation: Section 199A aggregation requires 50%+ common ownership and two or more factors: shared management, shared employees, centralized accounting, interdependent product/service lines. Aggregation must be consistently applied.
questions.tip: 199A aggregation: 50%+ ownership + shared business elements. Benefits W-2/property limitations.

questions.question: A father owns 100% of Corporation A and his son owns 100% of Corporation B. Under Section 318 attribution rules, are A and B related parties?

options.B: Yes—father is attributed son's ownership
options.C: Only if both corporations are C corporations
options.D: Only if the son is a minor

questions.explanation: Under Section 318, stock owned by a child is attributed to their parents (and vice versa). The father is deemed to own 100% of both corporations, creating a controlled group and related party status.
questions.tip: Family attribution: Parent ↔ child, spouse ↔ spouse. Creates deemed ownership.

questions.question: A C corporation accumulates $500,000 beyond the accumulated earnings credit. What tax consequence may apply?

options.B: 20% accumulated earnings tax on unreasonable accumulations

questions.explanation: The accumulated earnings tax is 20% of accumulated taxable income if a corporation accumulates earnings beyond reasonable business needs to avoid shareholder-level dividend tax. The $250,000 base credit applies.
questions.tip: AET: 20% penalty tax on accumulations beyond reasonable business needs.

questions.question: A holding company charges management fees to its operating subsidiaries. For the fees to be deductible by subsidiaries, they must be:

options.A: Any amount agreed upon by the parties
options.B: Reasonable and for actual services rendered
options.D: Approved by the IRS in advance

questions.explanation: Management fees between related parties must be reasonable in amount and for actual services rendered. The IRS can disallow deductions for excessive fees that don't reflect arm's length value or actual services.
questions.tip: Intercompany fees: Must be reasonable + actual services. Document thoroughly.

questions.question: A corporation owns a single-member LLC. For federal tax purposes, the LLC is:

options.B: Disregarded—treated as division of the corporation
options.D: A partnership with the corporation as partner

questions.explanation: A single-member LLC owned by a corporation is disregarded for federal tax purposes. Its income, deductions, and assets are reported as if directly owned by the corporate parent. This simplifies reporting while maintaining state law liability protection.
questions.tip: Single-member LLC = disregarded entity. Reports on owner's return. State law protection remains.

questions.question: A professional receives $150,000 from a partnership. $100,000 is a guaranteed payment for services. Which statement is correct?

options.A: All $150,000 is subject to self-employment tax
options.B: Only the $100,000 guaranteed payment is subject to SE tax
options.C: Neither amount is subject to SE tax
options.D: All $150,000 is wage income subject to withholding

questions.explanation: A general partner's share of partnership income (both guaranteed payments and distributive share) is generally subject to self-employment tax if from a trade or business. Partners are not employees—no withholding applies.
questions.tip: General partners: All partnership income subject to SE tax (trade/business).

questions.question: For a corporate spin-off to qualify as tax-free under Section 355, which requirement must be met?

options.A: The distributed subsidiary must have been owned for at least 6 months
options.B: Control of the subsidiary must be distributed to shareholders
options.C: The parent must retain at least 20% ownership

questions.explanation: Tax-free spin-offs under Section 355 require distribution of 'control' (80% of voting and value) to shareholders. Additional requirements include active trade or business for 5 years and valid business purpose.
questions.tip: Section 355: Distribute 80%+ control, 5-year active business, business purpose required.

questions.question: An owner makes a $50,000 loan to their business entity. How does this affect loss deduction basis in an S corp versus a partnership?

options.A: Increases basis equally in both entity types
options.B: Increases S corp basis only if direct loan to corporation
options.C: Increases partnership basis regardless of loan structure
options.D: Both B and C are correct

questions.explanation: S corp basis increases only for direct shareholder loans to the corporation. Partnership basis increases for the partner's share of all partnership liabilities, including bank loans to the partnership. This makes partnerships more favorable for loss deduction capacity.
questions.tip: S corp: Only direct loans increase basis. Partnership: Share of ALL liabilities increases basis.

questions.conceptTested: Ordinary loss on small business stock
questions.question: An individual owns Section 1244 stock that becomes worthless. What is the tax treatment of the $80,000 loss?

options.B: Ordinary loss up to $50,000 (single) or $100,000 (married)
options.C: Fully ordinary loss with no limit

questions.explanation: Section 1244 allows ordinary loss treatment (not capital loss) on small business stock up to $50,000 for single filers or $100,000 for married filing jointly per year. Excess loss is capital loss. The $80,000 loss would be $50,000 ordinary (single) or fully ordinary (MFJ).
questions.tip: Section 1244: Ordinary loss up to $50K/$100K per year. Valuable for startup failures.

questions.question: A closely held C corporation's income is primarily from investments. What additional tax may apply?

options.A: No additional tax for investment income
options.B: 20% personal holding company tax on undistributed PHC income

questions.explanation: Personal holding company (PHC) tax of 20% applies to undistributed PHC income if more than 50% owned by 5 or fewer individuals and 60%+ of adjusted ordinary gross income is PHC income (dividends, interest, rent under certain conditions, royalties).
questions.tip: PHC tax: 20% on undistributed income for investment-heavy closely held C corps.

questions.question: When can affiliated C corporations file a consolidated return?

options.B: Parent owns 80%+ of vote and value of subsidiaries

questions.explanation: Consolidated returns require an affiliated group where a common parent owns directly or indirectly 80%+ of voting power and 80%+ of value of each subsidiary's stock. S corps and certain other entities cannot be included.
questions.tip: Consolidated return: 80%+ vote AND value. Allows offsetting profits and losses.

questions.question: A qualified opportunity fund (QOF) must be organized as which type of entity?

options.B: Partnership only

questions.explanation: A QOF can be organized as a corporation or partnership (including an LLC taxed as either). The fund must hold at least 90% of its assets in qualified opportunity zone property. Most QOFs are structured as partnerships for pass-through treatment.
questions.tip: QOF: Corp or partnership OK. Most use partnership for pass-through + investor flexibility.

questions.question: Corporation A owns 80% of Corporation B. Corporation B owns 60% of Corporation C. Under Section 318, what percentage of C does A constructively own?
questions.explanation: Stock owned by a corporation is attributed proportionally to its shareholders. A owns 80% of B, which owns 60% of C. A's constructive ownership of C = 80% × 60% = 48%.
questions.tip: Entity-to-owner attribution: Proportional. 80% × 60% = 48% constructive ownership.

questions.question: After a corporation with $2 million NOL undergoes an ownership change, what limits the use of the NOL?

options.B: Section 382 limits annual NOL use based on company value times long-term tax-exempt rate
options.C: NOL can only offset 50% of income
options.D: 5-year waiting period before NOL can be used

questions.explanation: Section 382 limits annual NOL usage after an ownership change (>50% shift in 3 years). The limit equals the corporation's value times the long-term tax-exempt rate. This prevents 'trafficking' in loss corporations.
questions.tip: Section 382: Annual NOL limit = Corp value × long-term exempt rate. Anti-loss-trafficking.

questions.question: A tax-exempt investor uses a 'blocker corporation' to invest in a partnership generating UBTI. What is the primary tax benefit?

options.A: Eliminates all taxation on the investment
options.B: Converts UBTI to dividend income taxable only when distributed

questions.explanation: A C corporation blocker converts partnership UBTI into corporate income taxed at corporate rates. Tax-exempt investors receive only dividends (not UBTI) when distributed. This 'blocks' UBTI from the exempt investor at the cost of corporate-level tax.
questions.tip: Blocker corp: Converts UBTI to dividends. Tax cost = corporate tax rate on income.

questions.question: A partnership without a Section 754 election admits a new partner who pays $500,000 for a 25% interest. Inside basis of partnership assets is $1.6 million (partner's share: $400,000). What is the new partner's basis in partnership assets?

options.B: $500,000 (purchase price)
options.C: $400,000 without election; $500,000 adjustment available with election

questions.explanation: Without Section 754, the new partner's share of inside basis is $400,000. With a 754 election, a $100,000 special basis adjustment applies solely to the new partner, matching inside basis to the $500,000 purchase price.
questions.tip: Section 754: Aligns inside basis with outside basis for buying partner. Election required.

questions.question: A C corporation converts from Delaware to Texas incorporation. Under what type of reorganization is this tax-free?

options.B: Type B (stock-for-stock)

questions.explanation: A Type F reorganization covers 'mere changes in identity, form, or place of organization.' Changing state of incorporation without changing business operations qualifies. No gain or loss is recognized.
questions.tip: Type F: Identity/form/place changes. Useful for redomiciliation, conversion, etc.

questions.question: A law firm structured as an S corporation generates $800,000 of income. The shareholder's taxable income is $500,000 (MFJ). What Section 199A deduction is available?

options.B: $0 (SSTB fully phased out)
options.C: Partial deduction based on phase-out calculation

questions.explanation: Law firms are specified service trades or businesses (SSTB). For MFJ filers, SSTB deduction phases out between $364,200-$464,200 (2024). At $500,000, the phase-out is complete—no 199A deduction is available.
questions.tip: SSTB: No Section 199A above phase-out threshold. Law, accounting, medical are SSTB.

questions.question: An 'Up-C' structure used in IPOs involves:

options.A: Converting partnership to C corporation before IPO
options.B: Creating a C corporation parent that holds partnership units
options.D: Electing S corporation status after going public

questions.explanation: Up-C structure creates a C corporation holding company that IPOs while the underlying business remains a partnership. Original owners keep partnership units, preserving pass-through treatment. Public shareholders own C corp stock.
questions.tip: Up-C: C corp shell for IPO, partnership underneath. Preserves pass-through for founders.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells QSBS held for 4 years (not meeting the 5-year exclusion). Under Section 1045, gain may be deferred if:

options.A: Deferral is automatic for all QSBS
options.B: Proceeds are reinvested in other QSBS within 60 days
options.C: The stock was held for at least 3 years
options.D: No deferral is available for stock held less than 5 years

questions.explanation: Section 1045 allows deferral (not exclusion) of QSBS gain if held for at least 6 months and proceeds are reinvested in other QSBS within 60 days. This is useful when the 5-year holding period for exclusion hasn't been met.
questions.tip: Section 1045: Defer QSBS gain by reinvesting in other QSBS within 60 days. 6-month min hold.

questions.question: Partnership A owns a 40% interest in Partnership B. Partner X owns 25% of Partnership A. For Section 751 (hot asset) purposes, what is X's indirect interest in Partnership B's hot assets?
questions.explanation: Look-through rules apply to tiered partnerships. X's interest in B's assets = X's share of A (25%) × A's share of B (40%) = 10%. Hot asset character flows through to ultimate partners at their proportional share.
questions.tip: Tiered partnerships: Look through to ultimate partner. Multiply ownership percentages.

questions.question: A shareholder advances $500,000 to their closely held corporation with no fixed repayment terms, interest rate below market, and repayment subordinated to other creditors. The IRS may recharacterize this as:

options.B: Equity contribution

questions.explanation: The IRS examines multiple factors to distinguish debt from equity: fixed maturity, interest rate, debt-equity ratio, repayment terms, subordination. Here, the factors suggest equity. Recharacterization makes interest non-deductible and repayments potentially dividends.
questions.tip: Debt-equity factors: Maturity, rate, ratio, terms, subordination. Document loans properly.

questions.question: A high-income professional wants to minimize tax while protecting assets and preserving flexibility. Which structure best accomplishes these goals?

options.B: S corporation operating company with LLC holding company for real estate
options.C: C corporation to avoid pass-through income

questions.explanation: S corp minimizes SE tax and provides pass-through treatment. Separate LLC for real estate provides asset protection and rental losses (potentially deductible with REP status). This combination addresses self-employment, pass-through, and liability goals.
questions.tip: Common optimal structure: S corp for operations (SE tax savings) + LLC for real estate (protection).
